Identification.LongTitle: Social Security Tribunal Rules of Procedure

Provision.Text: Whereas, under subsection 45.1(2)a of the Department of Employment and Social Development Actb, the Minister of Employment and Social Development has approved the making of the annexed Social Security Tribunal Rules of Procedure;

Therefore, the Chairperson of the Social Security Tribunal makes the annexed Social Security Tribunal Rules of Procedure under subsection 45.1(2)a of the Department of Employment and Social Development Actb.

SignatureTitle.Language: Le président du Tribunal de la sécurité sociale,

SignatureBlock.SignatureTitle: Chairperson of the Social Security Tribunal

Subsection.Text: These Rules set out the procedure for appeals before the Tribunal. The Rules aim to help parties understand the appeal process and their roles and responsibilities. The Rules and the appeal process are meant to promote access to justice.
The Tribunal decides appeals from reconsideration decisions made under

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the Canada Pension Plan;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the Old Age Security Act; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the Employment Insurance Act.

Section.Text: The Tribunal is an independent administrative tribunal. It consists of the members of the General Division and Appeal Division. The members are appointed under Part 5 of the Department of Employment and Social Development Act. The Tribunal is supported by the Tribunal Secretariat. The Secretariat consists of employees of the Administrative Tribunals Support Service of Canada. The Secretariat carries out some administrative tasks related to these Rules for the Tribunal.
These Rules are set out in the order that they normally apply, but the order may be different in some appeals. Not every rule applies in every appeal. The Rules are divided into the following Parts:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: Part 1 sets out how to interpret the Rules;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: Part 2 sets out general rules about what the Tribunal can do and how it conducts the appeal process;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: Part 3 sets out the roles and responsibilities of participants and the Tribunal;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: Part 4 sets out how to file documents with the Tribunal and how the Tribunal handles documents;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: Part 5 sets out how to appeal, how the Tribunal handles late appeals, what language the appeal can be in and how the Tribunal adds parties;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: Part 6 sets out various procedures that may apply in the appeal process;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: Part 7 sets out specific rules for Income Security appeals at the General Division and Appeal Division;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: Part 8 sets out specific rules for Employment Insurance appeals at the General Division and Appeal Division;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: Part 9 sets out specific rules for hearings and decisions;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: Part 10 sets out how the Rules apply to appeals that are ongoing when the Rules start to apply; and

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: Part 11 sets out when the Rules start to apply.

Section.Text: This Part sets out definitions for terms and expressions used in these Rules. This Part also sets out how the Tribunal interprets and applies the Rules.
The following definitions apply in these Rules. To understand the Rules, it is important to first read the definitions and then refer back to them as needed.

Definition.Text: appeal means an appeal under Part 5 of the Department of Employment and Social Development Act. It includes an application for permission to appeal to the Appeal Division. (appel)

appellant means the person who appeals a reconsideration decision to the General Division or a General Division decision to the Appeal Division. At the Appeal Division, the appellant may also be the Minister or the Commission. (appelant)

argument means a submission that sets out a party’s point of view about what the Tribunal should do in an appeal. A party may file arguments with the Tribunal or make arguments at an oral hearing. (argument)
business day means a day that is not a Saturday, Sunday or holiday. (jour ouvrable)
Commission means the Canada Employment Insurance Commission. (Commission)

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an address;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a phone number, if there is one; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: an email address, if there is one. (coordonnées)

Definition.Text: Employment Insurance appeal means an appeal from a reconsideration decision that the Commission made under the Employment Insurance Act. (appel en assurance-emploi)

evidence means something that a party presents to the Tribunal to prove a fact. It includes documents, photographs, video recordings and sound recordings that a party may file with the Tribunal. It also includes testimony given at an oral hearing. (élément de preuve)
Income Security appeal means an appeal from a reconsideration decision that the Minister made under the Canada Pension Plan or the Old Age Security Act. (appel en sécurité du revenu)
Minister means the Minister of Employment and Social Development. (ministre)

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the parties; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: representatives, support persons, witnesses and interpreters who take part in an appeal. (participant)

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the appellant and the Minister, for Income Security appeals at the General Division;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the appellant and the Commission, for Employment Insurance appeals at the General Division;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the appellant and all other parties who were before the General Division, for appeals at the Appeal Division; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: any person added as a party under section 33. (partie)

Definition.Text: permission to appeal means leave to appeal a General Division decision to the Appeal Division under section 58 or 58.1 of the Department of Employment and Social Development Act. (permission de faire appel)

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a decision that the Minister made under section 81 of the Canada Pension Plan, including a decision about more time to make a reconsideration request and a decision to rescind or amend a decision based on new facts;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a decision that the Minister made under section 27.1 of the Old Age Security Act, including a decision about more time to make a reconsideration request; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a decision that the Commission made under section 112 of the Employment Insurance Act, including a decision about more time to make a reconsideration request. (décision de révision)

Definition.Text: reconsideration request means a request for the Minister or the Commission to reconsider a decision under

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: section 81(1) or (1.1) of the Canada Pension Plan;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: section 27.1(1) or (1.1) of the Old Age Security Act; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: section 112 of the Employment Insurance Act. (demande de révision)

Section.MarginalNote: How the Tribunal interprets and applies these Rules
Section.Text: The Tribunal must interpret and apply these Rules so that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the appeal process is simple, quick and fair;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the Tribunal considers the parties’ particular circumstances;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: every party can participate in the appeal process, even if they do not have a representative; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the appeal process is flexible and appropriate for what the Tribunal must decide in each appeal.

Section.Text: This Part sets out

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: how the Tribunal conducts the appeal process;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: what happens if the Tribunal cannot reach a party; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: how to ask for an accommodation.

Section.MarginalNote: Making the appeal process simple, quick and fair

Subsection.Text: The Tribunal must make sure that the appeal process is as simple and quick as fairness allows.

The Tribunal uses active adjudication as described in section 17(2) to help parties participate fully in the appeal process. This includes using methods other than the adversarial methods of adjudication the courts typically use.

Subsection.MarginalNote: If a party wants the Tribunal to decide on a procedure
Subsection.Text: A party may ask the Tribunal to do or decide something as part of the appeal process. To do this, the party must file a request with the Tribunal. The request must set out what the party wants and why.
The Tribunal may adapt these Rules or decide that a party does not need to follow one or more rules if it is in the interest of justice.

Subsection.MarginalNote: If these Rules do not cover something
Subsection.Text: The Tribunal may decide the procedure for anything not in these Rules or the Social Security Tribunal Regulations, 2022.

Heading.TitleText: Continuing the Appeal Process Without a Party

Subsection.Text: The Tribunal uses the contact information it has on file when it contacts a party or sends a document to a party.

Subsection.MarginalNote: If the Tribunal cannot reach a party
Subsection.Text: The Tribunal may continue the appeal process even if it cannot reach a party using the contact information the party gave it. The Tribunal may do this without giving further notice to the party.

In this section, accommodation means an arrangement to remove a barrier so a person can participate fully in the appeal process. An accommodation must relate to one of the grounds set out in section 3 of the Canadian Human Rights Act.

Subsection.MarginalNote: If a participant needs an accommodation
Subsection.Text: A participant must notify the Tribunal as soon as possible if they need an accommodation.

Section.Text: This Part sets out the roles and responsibilities of participants and the Tribunal.
Participants must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: be respectful and help maintain a safe environment;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: be honest; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: not act in any way that goes against these Rules, the Social Security Tribunal Regulations, 2022 or the appeal process.

Subsection.Text: Parties are responsible for participating in the appeal process. This may include

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: preparing documents;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: filing documents with the Tribunal;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: presenting evidence or arguments;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: attending a conference or a hearing;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: questioning witnesses; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: responding to another party’s arguments.

Subsection.Text: Parties must follow these Rules and the Tribunal’s directions. This includes

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: communicating with the Tribunal and responding to its requests; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: meeting the deadlines the Tribunal sets out.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Keeping contact information up to date
Subsection.Text: Parties must notify the Tribunal as soon as possible of any changes to their contact information.
If a party chooses to have a representative under section 63.1 of the Department of Employment and Social Development Act, the representative

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: acts on behalf of the party by presenting their position;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: may represent the party for all or part of the appeal process; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: does not need to be a lawyer.

Subsection.Text: A representative is responsible for participating in the appeal process in the same way that a party participates as described in section 13.
The Tribunal communicates directly with a representative. The representative must share information they receive from the Tribunal with the party they represent.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Keeping a representative’s contact information up to date
Subsection.Text: A representative must notify the Tribunal as soon as possible of any changes to their contact information.

Subsection.MarginalNote: If a representative stops representing a party
Subsection.Text: A representative must notify the Tribunal as soon as possible if they stop representing a party.
In this section and in Part 1, support person means a person who helps a party at an oral hearing by

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: organizing their documents;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: taking notes for the party; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: giving moral and emotional support.

Subsection.Text: A support person does not represent the party, but they may attend the oral hearing as an observer.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Sharing information with a support person
Subsection.Text: The Tribunal does not communicate directly with a support person outside an oral hearing. A party is responsible for sharing information from the Tribunal with their support person if they want the support person to have the information.
A witness testifies at an oral hearing to give relevant evidence.
A witness may be questioned by a party, a representative or the Tribunal. A witness must answer all questions truthfully.
The Tribunal hears appeals in a way that allows parties to participate fully in the appeal process. The Tribunal considers all of the parties’ evidence and arguments and gives a decision.
The Tribunal actively adjudicates appeals. Active adjudication may include

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: deciding what issues need to be addressed;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: deciding what procedures are appropriate in the circumstances;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: helping parties, representatives and witnesses understand the appeal process and these Rules;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: providing information about the laws that apply to the appeal;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: providing information about the evidence;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: deciding the order for parties to present evidence or arguments at an oral hearing; and

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: asking parties, representatives and witnesses questions.

Section.Text: This Part sets out

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: how to file documents with the Tribunal and what the Tribunal does with them;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: what the Tribunal can do with electronic documents; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: when the Tribunal considers that a party has received a document.

Subsection.Text: A party that needs to file a document with the Tribunal must file the document in one of the following ways:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: by email, using the address set out on the Tribunal’s website;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: by mail, using the address set out on the Tribunal’s website; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: electronically, using the electronic filing procedure set out on the Tribunal’s website.

Subsection.Text: A document is considered filed on the date the Tribunal receives it. On each document, the Tribunal indicates the date it received the document.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Extending a deadline that falls on a weekend or holiday
Subsection.Text: If a filing deadline set by the Tribunal or these Rules falls on a day that is not a business day, the deadline is extended to the next business day.

Section.MarginalNote: Adding documents to the appeal record

Subsection.Text: When a party files a document to support their position in an appeal, the Tribunal must add it to the appeal record.
When a party files a document to support their position in an appeal, the Tribunal must send a copy of it to the other parties as soon as possible.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Accessing documents in the appeal record
Subsection.Text: The public may access the documents in the appeal record unless the Tribunal limits public access to them under section 3 of the Social Security Tribunal Regulations, 2022.

Section.MarginalNote: An electronic copy is an original

Subsection.Text: An electronic copy of a document is considered the original version of the document.
The Tribunal may make an electronic copy of any document filed.
The Tribunal may provide an electronic copy of any document filed.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Certifying an electronic copy as a true copy
Subsection.Text: The Tribunal may certify an electronic copy as a true copy.

Section.MarginalNote: When a party receives a document by regular mail

Subsection.Text: When the Tribunal sends a document to a party by regular mail, the document is considered received 10 days after the day it was sent.

Subsection.MarginalNote: When a party receives a document by registered mail or courier
Subsection.Text: When the Tribunal sends a document to a party by registered mail or courier, the document is considered received on the date of the delivery confirmation receipt.

Subsection.MarginalNote: When a party receives a document electronically
Subsection.Text: When the Tribunal sends a document to a party by email or another electronic method, the document is considered received on the next business day.
The Tribunal applies sections 22(1) to (3) unless a party shows why the Tribunal should not apply them.

Section.Text: This Part sets out

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: how to appeal and what information to provide;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: how the Tribunal handles late appeals;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: what language the appeal can be in; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: how the Tribunal adds parties.

Section.MarginalNote: How to appeal a reconsideration decision to the General Division

Subsection.Text: To appeal a reconsideration decision, an appellant must file a notice of appeal with the Tribunal’s General Division. The notice must include

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the appellant’s full name;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the appellant’s contact information;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the appellant’s reasons for appealing;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the identifying number referred to in section 24(2); and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: a copy of the reconsideration decision or the date of the reconsideration decision.

Subsection.Text: The identifying number is the number that the Tribunal asks for on its website. The number may be

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a social insurance number;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a Canada Revenue Agency business number; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: any other identifying number that the Tribunal asks for.

Subsection.MarginalNote: When to file the notice of appeal
Subsection.Text: The appellant must file the notice of appeal by the deadline set out in section 52 of the Department of Employment and Social Development Act.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Confirming the notice of appeal was received
Subsection.Text: The Tribunal notifies the appellant when it receives their notice of appeal.

Section.MarginalNote: Notifying an employer about an Employment Insurance appeal
Section.Text: The Tribunal notifies an appellant’s employer or former employer about an Employment Insurance appeal at the General Division if the appeal is about one of the following situations:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: failing to take advantage of an opportunity for, apply for or accept suitable employment under section 27 of the Employment Insurance Act, if the reasons are work-related;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: losing or being suspended from an employment because of misconduct under section 30, 31 or 33 of the Employment Insurance Act;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: voluntarily leaving an employment under section 30 or 32 of the Employment Insurance Act, if the reasons are work-related; or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a labour dispute under section 36 of the Employment Insurance Act.

Section.MarginalNote: How to appeal a General Division decision to the Appeal Division

Subsection.Text: To appeal a General Division decision, an appellant must file an application for permission to appeal with the Tribunal’s Appeal Division. The application must include

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the appellant’s full name;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the appellant’s contact information;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the appellant’s reasons for appealing; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a copy of the General Division decision, the date of the General Division decision or the General Division file number.

Subsection.Text: The appellant must file the application for permission to appeal by the deadline set out in section 57 of the Department of Employment and Social Development Act.
To be granted permission to appeal, the appellant must show

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: for an Income Security appeal, that at least one of the criteria set out in section 58.1 of the Department of Employment and Social Development Act is met; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: for an Employment Insurance appeal, that there is a reasonable chance of success on at least one of the grounds of appeal set out in section 58 of the Department of Employment and Social Development Act.

Subsection.Text: The Tribunal notifies the appellant when it receives their application for permission to appeal.

Section.MarginalNote: How to ask for more time

Subsection.Text: An appellant who files a notice of appeal or an application for permission to appeal after the deadline must explain why they are late. They must file the explanation with the Tribunal.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Deciding to give more time to appeal
Subsection.Text: The Tribunal gives more time to appeal if the appellant has a reasonable explanation for why they are late. The Tribunal decides whether to give more time without asking the other parties for arguments.

Section.Text: A party may choose whether they want the appeal to be in English or French. This rule does not apply to the Minister or the Commission.

Section.MarginalNote: Documents not in English or French
Section.Text: A party who wants to file a document that is not in English or French must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: get the document translated into English or French; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: file the translation with the document.

Section.MarginalNote: Asking for a translation of a document filed by the Minister or Commission

Subsection.Text: If the Minister or the Commission files a document that is not in a party’s chosen language for the appeal, the party may ask the Tribunal for a translation of the document in that language.

If a party asks the Tribunal for a translation, the Minister or the Commission must get the document translated unless the document came from the party. The Minister or the Commission must file the translation with the Tribunal.

Section.MarginalNote: What to include with translated documents
Section.Text: If a party files a translation with the Tribunal, the party must include the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the translator’s full name;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the translator’s contact information; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a statement from the translator that the translation is accurate.

Section.MarginalNote: If a party needs an interpreter

Subsection.Text: A party must notify the Tribunal as soon as possible if they or any other participant need an interpreter to translate what people say at an oral hearing or conference.
The Tribunal provides an interpreter if a party asks for one.

Section.MarginalNote: When the Tribunal automatically adds a party

Subsection.Text: The Tribunal must add a person as a party to an appeal in the following situations:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: when the Minister notifies the Tribunal of that person under section 65 of the Department of Employment and Social Development Act; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: when an employer is appealing a reconsideration decision about that person’s entitlement to benefits under the Employment Insurance Act.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Other situations when the Tribunal could add a party
Subsection.Text: The Tribunal may decide to add a person as a party to an appeal if the person has a direct interest in the decision.

Subsection.MarginalNote: How to ask to be added as a party
Subsection.Text: A person who wants to be added as a party to an appeal must file a request with the Tribunal. The request must include

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: their full name;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: their contact information; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: an explanation of how they have a direct interest in the decision.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Deciding without arguments from other parties
Subsection.Text: The Tribunal decides whether to add a person without asking the other parties for arguments.

Heading.Label: PART 6
Heading.TitleText: Procedures that Apply in Certain Situations

Section.Text: This Part sets out various procedures that may apply in the appeal process.

Section.MarginalNote: When the Tribunal may join appeals
Section.Text: The Tribunal may deal with two or more appeals together if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the appeals raise a common question; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: joining the appeals is not unfair to the parties.

Heading.TitleText: Limiting Public Access to the Appeal

Section.MarginalNote: If a party wants to limit public access

Subsection.Text: A party may ask the Tribunal to limit public access to an oral hearing or the appeal record. To do this, the party must file a request with the Tribunal.

Subsection.MarginalNote: What information to include with the request
Subsection.Text: The party’s request must set out

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the serious risk described in section 3 of the Social Security Tribunal Regulations, 2022 that is leading the party to ask the Tribunal to limit public access;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the information or documents they want to limit public access to; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the reasons why reasonable alternative measures cannot adequately reduce the serious risk.

Subsection.Text: The Tribunal may hold a conference with the parties to talk about the appeal. A conference may include discussions about any matter, such as

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the step the appeal is at and the next steps in the appeal process;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the issues in the appeal;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the Tribunal’s authority to do or decide something;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the deadlines for filing documents; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: ways to settle the appeal without a hearing.

Subsection.Text: A conference may take place

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: by phone;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: by video or other type of telecommunication; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in person.

Section.MarginalNote: If a conference is a settlement conference

Subsection.Text: If a conference is a settlement conference, documents related to the conference and discussions at the conference must not be disclosed. The documents are not part of the appeal record.
If all parties agree, the documents and discussions may be disclosed and the documents may be included in the appeal record.

Subsection.MarginalNote: If there is a hearing after a settlement conference
Subsection.Text: The Tribunal member who holds a settlement conference must not hear the appeal unless all parties agree.

Section.MarginalNote: If the parties reach an agreement

Subsection.Text: Parties may ask the Tribunal to make a decision based on an agreement they have reached and signed. To do this, parties must file a request and the agreement with the Tribunal.
Parties do not need to file a request or the agreement if they reach the agreement at a settlement conference.

Section.MarginalNote: Having a witness at an oral hearing
Section.Text: A party may have a witness testify at an oral hearing in the following types of appeals:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an Employment Insurance appeal at the General Division;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: an Income Security appeal at the General Division; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: an Income Security appeal at the Appeal Division.

Section.MarginalNote: How to notify the Tribunal about a witness in an Income Security appeal

Subsection.Text: If a party wants to have a witness testify in an Income Security appeal, the party must file a notice with the Tribunal by the filing deadline. The notice must include the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the witness’s full name;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the relationship between the party and the witness; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the language the witness will use to testify.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Other information to include about certain witnesses
Subsection.Text: If a witness is testifying as a professional, the notice must also include the following:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the witness’s résumé; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a list of the documents filed with the Tribunal that the witness will testify about or a summary of what the witness will testify about.

Subsection.Text: Section 41(2) does not apply to a witness who is a health care professional who treated the party seeking benefits.
The Tribunal does not qualify any witness as an expert before admitting the witness’s evidence.
If a party wants to testify, they do not need to file a notice.

Section.MarginalNote: If a party files evidence after a deadline

Subsection.Text: The Tribunal must not consider any evidence that a party files after a filing deadline set by the Tribunal or these Rules unless it gives the party permission to use that evidence.
When deciding whether to give a party permission, the Tribunal must consider any relevant factor. For example, the Tribunal considers whether

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the evidence is relevant;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the evidence is new;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the party could have filed the evidence earlier;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: giving permission would be unfair to a party; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: giving permission would cause delays.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Deciding without arguments from other parties
Subsection.Text: The Tribunal decides whether to give permission without asking the other parties for arguments unless fairness requires the Tribunal to ask.
A party may ask the Tribunal to reschedule a hearing. The Tribunal must reschedule the hearing when the party meets the following conditions:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: they are asking for the first time;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: they ask at least five business days before the hearing; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: they are available for a hearing within two weeks of the original hearing date.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Explaining why the hearing needs to be rescheduled
Subsection.Text: If a party wants to reschedule a hearing but does not meet the conditions set out in section 43(1), the party must file a request with the Tribunal. The request must explain why they want the hearing rescheduled.

The Tribunal may reschedule the hearing only if it is necessary for a fair hearing. The Tribunal decides whether to reschedule without asking the other parties for arguments unless fairness requires the Tribunal to ask.

Section.Text: An appellant may withdraw their appeal. They may do this by notifying the Tribunal anytime

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: before the hearing ends, when there is an oral hearing; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: before the Tribunal gives its decision, when there is a hearing in writing.

Section.Text: This Part sets out specific rules for Income Security appeals at the General Division and Appeal Division.

Heading.TitleText: Income Security Appeals at the General Division

Subsection.Text: The Minister must file the reconsideration file with the Tribunal within 20 days after the day the Minister receives a copy of the notice of appeal.

Subsection.MarginalNote: What to include with the reconsideration file
Subsection.Text: The reconsideration file must include a copy of the following:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the application that led to the reconsideration request;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the reconsideration request;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the reconsideration decision; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: all other relevant documents, including, if applicable,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the notification referred to in section 46 or 46.1 of the Canada Pension Plan Regulations,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: a document that sets out the information referred to in section 54(2) of the Canada Pension Plan Regulations,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the notice referred to in section 60(7) of the Canada Pension Plan, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: the notice referred to in section 16 or 24 of the Old Age Security Act.

Subsection.Text: The Tribunal must send the parties the deadlines for filing evidence, arguments or any other documents.

Subsection.MarginalNote: If a party is filing evidence, arguments or other documents
Subsection.Text: Parties must file any evidence, arguments or other documents by the filing deadlines.
The Tribunal may change the filing deadlines if it considers the change necessary. The Tribunal must then send the parties the new deadlines.
The Tribunal must not set a filing deadline that falls more than two years after the day the appellant filed the notice of appeal unless there are exceptional circumstances.

Heading.TitleText: Income Security Appeals at the Appeal Division

Section.MarginalNote: Asking for more information — permission to appeal

Subsection.Text: The Tribunal may ask an appellant for more information before it decides whether to grant permission to appeal a General Division decision.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Deciding without arguments from other parties
Subsection.Text: The Tribunal decides whether to grant permission to appeal without asking the other parties for arguments.
If it grants permission to appeal, the Tribunal must send the parties the deadlines for filing evidence, arguments or any other documents.

Subsection.MarginalNote: If a party is filing evidence, arguments or other documents
Subsection.Text: Parties must file any evidence, arguments or other documents by the filing deadlines.
The Tribunal may change the filing deadlines if it considers the change necessary. The Tribunal must then send the parties the new deadlines.

Section.Text: This Part sets out specific rules for Employment Insurance appeals at the General Division and Appeal Division.

Heading.TitleText: Employment Insurance Appeals at the General Division

Subsection.Text: The Commission must file the reconsideration file with the Tribunal within seven business days after the day the Commission receives a copy of the notice of appeal.

Subsection.MarginalNote: What to include with the reconsideration file
Subsection.Text: The reconsideration file must include a copy of the following:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the reconsideration request;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the reconsideration decision;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: all other relevant documents; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a document that sets out the Commission’s arguments, if it has any.

Section.MarginalNote: If a party is filing evidence
Section.Text: Parties must file any evidence before the hearing ends.

Section.MarginalNote: Asking the Commission to investigate and report
Section.Text: The Tribunal may ask the Commission to investigate and report on any question related to a claim for benefits. The Tribunal may do this anytime before giving its decision.

Heading.TitleText: Employment Insurance Appeals at the Appeal Division

Section.MarginalNote: Asking for more information — permission to appeal

Subsection.Text: The Tribunal may ask an appellant for more information before it decides whether to grant permission to appeal a General Division decision.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Deciding without arguments from other parties
Subsection.Text: The Tribunal decides whether to grant permission to appeal without asking the other parties for arguments.
If the Tribunal grants permission to appeal, the parties must file any arguments no more than 45 days after the day the Tribunal grants permission.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Deadline for filing arguments — hearing in writing
Subsection.Text: When there is a hearing in writing, the Tribunal must give parties 15 days to file any arguments in response to another party’s position.

Section.Text: This Part sets out specific rules for hearings and decisions.
If there will be a hearing, the Tribunal must send the parties a notice that sets out the hearing details.

Section.MarginalNote: When an oral hearing may take place without a party
Section.Text: An oral hearing may take place without a party if the Tribunal is of the opinion that the party received the notice of hearing.

Section.MarginalNote: When the Tribunal gives its decision
Section.Text: The Tribunal must give its decision as soon as possible after the hearing. The Tribunal must give reasons for its decision.
The following definitions apply in this Part.

Definition.Text: former Act means the Department of Employment and Social Development Act as it read immediately before the day these Rules come into force. (ancienne loi)
former Regulations means the Social Security Tribunal Regulations as they read immediately before the day these Rules come into force. (ancien règlement)

Section.MarginalNote: How these Rules apply to ongoing appeals
Section.Text: Subject to sections 62 to 64, these Rules apply to appeals that are ongoing on the day these Rules come into force.

Section.MarginalNote: Exception for ongoing Income Security appeals at the General Division

Subsection.Text: Sections 46, 47 and 57 of these Rules do not apply to Income Security appeals at the General Division that are ongoing on the day these Rules come into force. For those appeals, sections 26 to 28 of the former Regulations continue to apply.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Exception for ongoing Income Security appeals at the Appeal Division
Subsection.Text: Sections 40 to 42, 48, 49 and 57 of these Rules do not apply to Income Security appeals at the Appeal Division that are ongoing on the day these Rules come into force. For those appeals, sections 41 to 43 of the former Regulations continue to apply.

Section.MarginalNote: Exception for appeals of summary dismissal decisions to the Appeal Division
Section.Text: Sections 40 to 42, 48, 49, 54, 55 and 57 of these Rules do not apply to appeals of summary dismissal decisions made under section 53 of the former Act. For those appeals, sections 34 to 37 of the former Regulations continue to apply.

Section.MarginalNote: Exception for ongoing applications to rescind or amend a decision

Subsection.Text: Sections 40 to 42, Parts 7 and 8 and section 57 of these Rules do not apply to applications made under section 66 of the former Act that are ongoing on the day these Rules come into force. For those applications, sections 47 and 48 of the former Regulations continue to apply.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Exception for appeals of rescind or amend decisions to the Appeal Division
Subsection.Text: Sections 40 to 42, Parts 7 and 8 and section 57 of these Rules do not apply to appeals of decisions made under section 66 of the former Act. For those appeals, sections 41 to 43 of the former Regulations continue to apply.

Section.MarginalNote: When these Rules start to apply
Section.Text: These Rules come into force on the day Division 20 of Part 4 of the Budget Implementation Act, 2021, No. 1, chapter 23 of the Statutes of Canada, 2021, comes into force, but if they are registered after that day, they come into force on the day they are registered.
